# Instructions for editing this database													
# - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -													
# Specify functional groups based on taxon names.													
 # Each group begins with a group name, followed by a list of taxons affiliated with that group ('member taxons', one member per line). 													
# Groups are separated by at least one blank or pure-whitespace line.													
# Member taxons can be enclosed in quotes.													
# Comments are prefixed with # and will be ignored. Use comments to provide literature references for functional affiliations.													
#													
 # Each member is specified as a list of descending taxonomic levels (typically 2 or 3), separated by an asterisk (*). 													
 #    For example   *Escherichia*Coli*   or   *Proteobacteria*Nitrosomonas*   or   *Bacteria*Nitrosomonas*europaea*  . 													
#    The prefixed and suffixed asterisks indicate that there may be higher or lower taxonomic levels that haven't been included in the member name.													
 #    Be as general as possible, but as specific as needed to ensure the validity of the functional affiliations. 													
 #    For example, if all Nitrosomonas but not all Proteobacteria oxidize ammonia, then add *Proteobacteria*Nitrosomonas* instead of *Proteobacteria*, and instead of just *Proteobacteria*Nitrosomonas*europaea*. 													
#													
# Taxon names are case-insensitive.													
# Overlaps between groups are allowed.													
# Duplicate entries within a group are allowed (and will be ignored).													
 # Prefixed or trailing whitespace is ignored, unless enclosed in quotes. 													
# Group names should not contain whitespace characters (e.g. tabs).													
#													
# Set operations between functional groups are also supported:													
#    Adding previously defined groups to a new group (e.g. for group nesting) is done using the prefix 'add_group:'													
 #        For example, the group 'mammal_pathogens' may include 'add_group:human_pathogens' and 'add_group:cattle_pathogens' 													
 #    Similarly, to subtract previously defined groups from a new group (set difference), use the prefix 'subtract_group:' 													
 #    To form the intersection of a group with a previously defined group, use the prefix 'intersect_group:' 													
 #        For example, the group 'hydrogenotrophic_methanogens' may be defined by the two operations 'add_group:hydrogenotrophy' and 'intersect_group:methanogens'. 													
 #    The order of set operations matters, because a set operation applies to group definitions until the point of the set operation. 													
 #        For example, the group 'obligate_aerobic' may include 'add_group:aerobic' and then 'subtract_group:anaerobic'. 													
 #        Similarly, the group 'obligate_aerobic_and_others' may start with 'add_group:aerobic', then 'subtract_group:anaerobic', and then list additional members not affected by the set operations. 													
#													
 # Group names may be appended by an optional semicolon-separated list of metadata entries, which is separated by the group name by whitespace 													
#	 These metadata may be included in the generated function tables, but they do not unfluence which OTU/taxon is assigned to which function. 												
# 	 Each metadata entry should be of the format <key>:<value>, where <value> is a comma-separated list of values (whitespace is ignored) 												
#	 For example, methanogenesis may be appended by   carbon:yes; anaerobic:yes; elements:C,H   												
													
													
manganese_oxidation			elements:Mn; main_element:Mn; electron_donor:Mn; electron_acceptor:variable; aerobic:variable; exclusively_prokaryotic:yes; light_dependent:no										
# - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -

sulfate_respiration

dimethylsulfoniopropionate_demethylation			elements:S; main_element:S; electron_donor:S; electron_acceptor:variable; aerobic:yes; exclusively_prokaryotic:yes; light_dependent:no										
 #Dimethylsulfide (DMS) is the main component of marine emissions of volatile sulfur, contributing an estimated 98% of atmospheric DMS [2]. DMS is produced in the marine environment by degradation of its precursor dimethylsulfoniopropionate (DMSP) [3], which in turn is synthesized by microalgae and cyanobacteria starting from seawater sulfate. Here it can be oxidized by the action ofradical species such as OH, BrO, Cl and/or NO3, through several intermediate reac- tions, forming a variety ofproducts such as sulfur dioxide (SO2), methanesulfonic acid (MSA) and and dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) [1,4,5]. MSA (formula CH3SO3H, the smallest organic sulfonic acid) is one ofthe main products of DMS oxidation since it is estimated that 25–70% ofthe flux ofdimethylsulfide is oxidized to methanesulfonate (approximately 1010 Kg/year) [2,6–10]. Due to its hygroscopic nature, MSA takes part in the formation of cloud condensation nuclei (CCN), contributes to the regulation ofcloud formation and thus has a significant impact on albedo regulation [4,11,12]. 			#DOI: 10.1371/journal.pone.0125735										
# - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -	#dimethylsulfoniopropionate_demethylation		#https://www.uniprot.org/uniprot/?query=dimethylsulfoniopropionate+DMSP&sort=score; https://www.microbiologyresearch.org/content/journal/micro/10.1099/mic.0.038927-0	#dimethylsulfoniopropionate_demethylation

methanesulfonate_oxidation			elements:S; main_element:S; electron_donor:S; electron_acceptor:variable; aerobic:yes; exclusively_prokaryotic:yes; light_dependent:no										
 #Dimethylsulfide (DMS) is the main component of marine emissions of volatile sulfur, contributing an estimated 98% of atmospheric DMS [2]. DMS is produced in the marine environment by degradation of its precursor dimethylsulfoniopropionate (DMSP) [3], which in turn is synthesized by microalgae and cyanobacteria starting from seawater sulfate. Here it can be oxidized by the action ofradical species such as OH, BrO, Cl and/or NO3, through several intermediate reac- tions, forming a variety ofproducts such as sulfur dioxide (SO2), methanesulfonic acid (MSA) and and dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) [1,4,5]. MSA (formula CH3SO3H, the smallest organic sulfonic acid) is one ofthe main products of DMS oxidation since it is estimated that 25–70% ofthe flux ofdimethylsulfide is oxidized to methanesulfonate (approximately 1010 Kg/year) [2,6–10]. Due to its hygroscopic nature, MSA takes part in the formation of cloud condensation nuclei (CCN), contributes to the regulation ofcloud formation and thus has a significant impact on albedo regulation [4,11,12]. ]. MSA can be used as a sulfur source by some aerobic bacte- ria [10]. On the other hand, several methylotrophic bacteria isolated from different environ- ments have shown the ability to grow using MSA as the sole source ofcarbon and energy. 			#DOI: 10.1371/journal.pone.0125735										
# - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -

methanotrophy_aerobic_ammonia_oxidation			 elements:C, N; main_element:C,N; electron_donor:_; electron_acceptor:variable; aerobic:yes; exclusively_prokaryotic:yes; light_dependent:no 										
#Both grow obligately on their particular substrate (NH3 for nitrifiers and CH4 for methanotrophs) but are capable of cooxidising the alternative substrate.			#https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1002/9780470015902.a0022213	 #https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Structure/cdd/cddsrv.cgi?uid=TIGR03079; #https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Structure/sparcle/archview.html?archid=10022115; https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Structure/cdd/cddsrv.cgi?uid=383882; https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC91262/#:~:text=Both%20methane%2D%20and%20ammonia%2Doxidizing,other%20substrate%20analogues%20(5).

add_group:methanotrophy_aerobic_ammonia_oxidation			#https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Structure/cdd/cddsrv.cgi?uid=TIGR03079; #https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Structure/sparcle/archview.html?archid=10022115; https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Structure/cdd/cddsrv.cgi?uid=383882	#CH4_NH3mon_ox_B									
### *Archaea*Thaumarchaeota*	#ammonia-oxidizing archaea		# DOI:10.1128/AEM.01960-12  and  DOI:10.1146/annurev-micro-092611-150128										
### *Thaumarchaeota*Marine Group I*						# DOI:10.1371/journal.pone.0095380							
###*Archaea*Thaumarchaeota*Nitrososphaeria*Nitrososphaerales*Nitrososphaeraceae*	#ammonia-oxidizing archaea		 #Pester M, Rattei T, Flechl S, Gröngröft A, Richter A, Overmann J, Reinhold-Hurek B, Loy A, Wagner M. amoA-based consensus phylogeny of ammonia-oxidizing archaea and deep sequencing of amoA genes from soils of four different geographic regions. Environ Microbiol. 2012 Feb;14(2):525-39. doi: 10.1111/j.1462-2920.2011.02666.x. Epub 2011 Dec 5. PMID: 22141924; PMCID: PMC3328746. 	 Estimation of the mean pH preference of the most abundant clusters defined by the amoA gene confirmed pH specialisation for the acidophilic clusters Nitrosotalea C14 and Nitrososphaera C11 and neutro-alkalinophilic clusters Nitrososphaera C1/2 and C12 (Supplementary Figure S3) (Gubry-Rangin et al., 2011). Distribution of the most abundant 16S rRNA-defined clusters along the pH gradient indicated five neutro-alkalinophilic clusters (Nitrososphaera K, L, I, O and G) and four acidophilic clusters (Nitrosotalea P, Nitrososphaera A, Group 1.1c GC1 and Group 1.1c GC5) (Supplementary Figure S4). Furthermore, all Group 1.1c and Group 1.3 clusters were acidophilic, the majority being extreme acidophiles (Supplementary Figure S2). In addition to the pH preference of these clusters, multivariate statistical analysis was used to infer mean preferences for two additional environmental factors (organic matter and water contents) that were available for all soils. This indicated that AOA are generally associated with lower soil water and organic matter content than Group 1.1c and Group 1.3 (Supplementary Figure S2), both of which were detected most frequently in forest ecosystems. 									
###*Archaea*Thaumarchaeota*Nitrososphaeria*Nitrosotaleales*Nitrosotaleaceae*Nitrosotalea*	#ammonia-oxidizing archaea		 #Clingenpeel, Scott, et al.   Yellowstone lake nanoarchaeota.   Frontiers in microbiology 4 (2013): 274. 	https://journals.plos.org/plosbiology/article?id=10.1371/journal.pbio.3000106									
*Archaea*Crenarchaeota*Thermoprotei*	#ammonia-oxidizing archaea		 Munson-McGee et al., 2015; Andersson et al., 2005; Großkopf et al.,  1998 	 Nanoarchaeota ribosomal sequences have been widespread detected in terrestrial hot springs, mesophilic hypersaline environments, photic-zone water samples removed from hydrothermal vents; symbionts/parasites with a highly reduced genome lacking most biosynthetic capacity and found in association with their host such as marine hyperthermophilic,  diplomonads, parabasalid, Entamoeba, and ciliate 									
*Archaea*Nanoarchaeaeota*Woesearchaeia*	#ammonia-oxidizing archaea		 Munson-McGee et al., 2015; Andersson et al., 2005; Großkopf et al.,  1998 	deeper zones marine sediments; facultative interdependent of SRB (CH4 utilized with metal oxides in finel e- receptor); methanogens									
*Archaea*Thaumarchaeota*Group_1.1c*	#ammonia-oxidizing archaea		 Oton et al., 2016; Stiegimeier et al., 2014; Weber et al., 2015 	 sequences in acidic forest soils (Jurgens, Lindström and Saano 1997; Bomberg and Timonen 2009) in pH range 4.5–6.0) (Lehtovirta, Prosser and Nicol 2009). Weber, E. B., Lehtovirta-Morley, L. E., Prosser, J. I., & Gubry-Rangin, C. (2015), mixed deciduous forest (Kemnitz, Kolb and Conrad 2007), tropical savannah soil (Catão et al., 2013); acetate microcosms converted to acetic acid below pH 5.5 might indicate adaptation or tolerance of Group 1.1c to high concentrations of acetic acid; mixotrophic growth of cultivated AOA (Tourna et al., 2008; Lehtovirta-Morley et al., 2014); assimilation of amino acids by marine ammonia-oxidizing Thaumarchaeota (Ouverney and Fuhrman 2000; Ingalls et al., 2006)(Oton et al., 2016; Stiegimeier et al., 2014; Weber et al., 2015; *Present higher GC content than other Group 1 Thaumarchaeota (Delong 1998; Nicol et al., 2007).*

*Thaumarchaeota*Marine Group I*	#ammonia-oxidizing archaea		# DOI:10.1371/journal.pone.0095380										
*Thaumarchaeota*Nitrosopelagicus*	#ammonia-oxidizing archaea		# DOI:10.1073/pnas.1416223112  and  DOI:10.1038/sdata.2016.50  (mainly genomic information)										
*Thaumarchaeota*Nitrososphaera*	#ammonia-oxidizing archaea		# DOI:10.1111/j.1462-2920.2011.02666.x	 Estimation of the mean pH preference of the most abundant clusters defined by the amoA gene confirmed pH specialisation for the acidophilic clusters Nitrosotalea C14 and Nitrososphaera C11 and neutro-alkalinophilic clusters Nitrososphaera C1/2 and C12 (Supplementary Figure S3) (Gubry-Rangin et al., 2011). Distribution of the most abundant 16S rRNA-defined clusters along the pH gradient indicated five neutro-alkalinophilic clusters (Nitrososphaera K, L, I, O and G) and four acidophilic clusters (Nitrosotalea P, Nitrososphaera A, Group 1.1c GC1 and Group 1.1c GC5) (Supplementary Figure S4). Furthermore, all Group 1.1c and Group 1.3 clusters were acidophilic, the majority being extreme acidophiles (Supplementary Figure S2). In addition to the pH preference of these clusters, multivariate statistical analysis was used to infer mean preferences for two additional environmental factors (organic matter and water contents) that were available for all soils. This indicated that AOA are generally associated with lower soil water and organic matter content than Group 1.1c and Group 1.3 (Supplementary Figure S2), both of which were detected most frequently in forest ecosystems.

nitrite_ammonification			elements:N; main_element:N; electron_donor:variable; electron_acceptor:N; aerobic:no; exclusively_prokaryotic:yes; light_dependent:no										
# - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -													
add_group:nitrate_ammonification	#nitrite_ammonification		# assuming that all nitrate ammonifiers are also nitrite ammonifiers

nitrite_respiration			elements:N; main_element:N; electron_donor:variable; electron_acceptor:N; aerobic:no; exclusively_prokaryotic:no; light_dependent:no

nitrification			 elements:N,O; main_element:N; electron_donor:N; electron_acceptor:O; aerobic:yes; exclusively_prokaryotic:yes; light_dependent:no 										
# - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -													
add_group:aerobic_ammonia_oxidation	#nitrification												
add_group:aerobic_nitrite_oxidation	#nitrification												
													
													
													
denitrification			elements:N; main_element:N; electron_donor:variable; electron_acceptor:N; aerobic:no; exclusively_prokaryotic:no; light_dependent:no										
 # dissimilatory reduction of fixed nitrogen compounds (NO3, NO2, N2O ...) to dinitrogen (N2) 													
# - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -													
add_group:nitrate_denitrification	#denitrification												
add_group:nitrite_denitrification	#denitrification												
add_group:nitrous_oxide_denitrification	#denitrification												
*Pseudomonas*fluorescens*	#denitrification		# DOI:10.1007/BF00413383										
*Pseudomonas*frederiksbergensis*	#denitrification		# DOI:10.1099/00207713-50-6-1957										
*Marinobacter*maritimus*	#denitrification		# DOI:10.1099/ijs.0.63478-0										
													
													
													
nitrogen_respiration			elements:N; main_element:N; electron_donor:variable; electron_acceptor:N; aerobic:no; exclusively_prokaryotic:no; light_dependent:no										
# dissimilatory reduction of nitrogen compounds													
# - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -													
add_group:nitrate_respiration	#nitrogen_respiration												
add_group:nitrite_respiration	#nitrogen_respiration												
add_group:denitrification	#nitrogen_respiration												
add_group:nitrate_ammonification	#nitrogen_respiration												
add_group:nitrite_ammonification	#nitrogen_respiration												
add_group:anammox	#nitrogen_respiration

*Oscillochloris*trichoides*	#ureolysis							 # Garrity, Brenner, Krieg and Staley (2001) Bergey's Manual of Systematic Bacteriology, vol. 1 					
													
													
aerobic_acetogenesis			elements:C; main_element:C; electron_donor:variable; electron_acceptor:C; aerobic:no; exclusively_prokaryotic:yes; light_dependent:no										
 #numerous fermentative bacteria hydrolyze the polymers and ferment the hydrolysis products to acetate and longer chain fatty acids, CO2, formate, H2 (McInerney et al., 2008; Schink, 1997). Acetogenic bacteria use methanol (from methyl groups of pectin), methyl groups of methoxylated aromatic compounds, some hydroxylated aromatic com- pounds, and H2 and CO2 to produce acetate (Drake, 1994).A second group of microorgan- isms works cooperatively with methanogenic bacteria to syntrophically metabolize the products of fermentative metabolism (e.g., propionate and longer chain fatty acids, alcohols, and aromatic acids) to the methanogenic substrates, H2, formate, and acetate. In syntrophic metabolism, the degradation of the parent compound, e.g., the fatty acid, is thermodynami- cally unfavorable unless the hydrogen, formate and acetate produced by the fatty acid degrader are kept low by the partner methanogens (>Table 2). L 			 #M. J. McInerney . T. Hoehler2 . R. P. Gunsalus . B. Schink. 2010. “Introduction to Microbial Hydrocarbon Production: Bioenergetics.” In Handbook of Hydrocarbon and Lipid Microbiology, Elsevier, 321–35.

*Bathyarchaeia*	#reductive_acetogenesis	 #silva v.138, YES 	 #;Kallistova et al., 2017; Bizic-Ionescu et al., 2019 	 #; methyl-reducing and methylotrophic methanogenesis  + acetogenesis(Kallistova et al., 2017; Bizic-Ionescu et al., 2018); utilize CO2 for methanogenesis from TMA and acetogenesis; BCR complex in aromatic degradation 									
*Lokiarchaeia* 	#reductive_acetogenesis	 #silva v.138, YES 	 # Farag, Ibrahim F. et al. 2020. “Metabolic Potentials of Archaeal Lineages Resolved from Metagenomes of Deep Costa Rica Sediments.” ISME Journal. http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/s41396-020-0615-5. 	 # genes encoding for ?-oxidation enzymes (enoyl-CoA hydratase, acyl CoA dehydrogenase, and acetyl CoA acetyl transferase) and various fermentation pathways (acetate and formate) in Lokiarchaeota CR_06, which suggests that short chain fatty acid and different fermentation products could also be syntrophically exchanged (Table S4). Also, # BCR complex. Utilize aromatic hydrocarbons for acetogenesis and donate electrons for nitrite reducers in syntrophy; utilize butanoate and propionate and donates eelectrons for sulfite-reducers in syntrophy. The best conditions suggest that the degradation of benzoate (the central metabolic intermediate in aromatic hydrocarbon degradation pathways) potentially occurs under the following metabolic conditions (a, b, and c): (a) benzoate mineraliza- tion to CO2 and H2O coupled with nitrite reduction to ammonia (?rG? =?1206.3 [kJ/mol]); (b) benzoate miner- alization to CO2 and H2O coupled with sulfite reduction to hydrogen sulfide (?rG? =?373.6 [kJ/mol]); and (c) benzoate mineralization to CO2 and H2O coupled with nitrate reduc- tion to nitrite (?rG? =?119.9 [kJ/mol]).  The affiliations of the BCR complex related proteins, BCRA and BCRB in Lokiarchaeota CR_06 were confirmed by the following observations: (1) contigs encoding for the four subunits of BCR complex fall within the same cover- age and GC% range of the rest of the contigs in the same MAG (Fig. S2); (2) phylogenetic trees of the BzdO and Q protein sequences detected in the CR_06 were placed as siblings to BCR sequences belonging to Lokiarchaeota MAGs recovered from deep sediment from south China Sea (GenBank accession numbers TET61664 and TKJ21612). Lokiarchaeota (CR_06) MAG also suggests versatile catabolic capacities potentially targeting detrital proteins and short chain fatty acids (e.g., propano- ate, butyrate), which are abundant in benthic marine sedi- ments. . Both propanoate and oxobutanoate are converted to propanoyl CoA via formate acetyl transferase and acetyl synthase, respectively. Then, the resulting pro- panoyl CoA is converted to acetyl-CoA via the malonyl- CoA pathway. CR_06 as well as other Asgard phyla showed different autotrophic capacities enabling carbon fixation using both the Wood–Ljungdahl (WL) pathway and the reverse tricaboxylic acid (rTCA) cycle.

methanogenesis_using_formate			elements:C; main_element:C; electron_donor:C; electron_acceptor:C; aerobic:no; exclusively_prokaryotic:yes; light_dependent:no										
 # formate is split internally into CO2 and H2, from which methaner is subsequently formed [DOI:10.1038/nrmicro1931] 			#	#

*Methanothermus*	#methanogenesis_using_formate		 #;Stetter et al., 1981; Lauerer et al., 1986 	 #;extremely thermophilic methanogen isolated from a hot spring (solfatara fields)(Stetter et al., 1981; Lauerer et al., 1986 									
													
													
syntrophy_hydrogenotrophs 			 elements:C,H; main_element:C; electron_donor:_; electron_acceptor:_; aerobic:no; exclusively_prokaryotic:yes; light_dependent:no 										
#			 #M. J. McInerney . T. Hoehler2 . R. P. Gunsalus . B. Schink. 2010. “Introduction to Microbial Hydrocarbon Production: Bioenergetics.” In Handbook of Hydrocarbon and Lipid Microbiology, Elsevier, 321–35. 	 #A second group of microorgan- isms works cooperatively with methanogenic bacteria to syntrophically metabolize the products of fermentative metabolism (e.g., propionate and longer chain fatty acids, alcohols, and aromatic acids) to the methanogenic substrates, H2, formate, and acetate. In syntrophic metabolism, the degradation of the parent compound, e.g., the fatty acid, is thermodynami- cally unfavorable unless the hydrogen, formate and acetate produced by the fatty acid degrader are kept low by the partner methanogens

Insights into the metabolism, lifestyle and putative evolutionary history of the novel archaeal phylum “Diapherotrites.” ISME Journal, 9(2), 447–460. https://doi.org/10.1038/ismej.2014.141 	 #;free-living lifestyle by channeling a narrow range of substrates such as ribose, polyhydroxybutyrate and several amino acids to acetyl-coenzyme A. ;Youssef, N. H., Rinke, C., Stepanauskas, R., Farag, I., Woyke, T., & Elshahed, M. S. (2015). #*Archaea*Euryarchaeota*Methanomicrobia*Methanosarcinales*Methanosarcinaceae*Methanomethylovorans*	#methanogenesis_by_reduction_of_methyl_compounds_with_H2		 #;Lomans et al., 1999; Jiang et al., 2005; Cha et al., 2013 	 #;methyl-reducer methanogen (methanogenesis from methanol, dimethylsulfie and methanethiol) from freshwater sediment; thermophilic methylotrophic methanogenesis from anerobic reactor; wetland sediment(Lomans et al., 1999; Jiang et al., 2005; Cha et al., 2013 									
#*Archaea*Euryarchaeota*Methanomicrobia*Methanosarcinales*Methanosarcinaceae*Methanosarcina*	#methanogenesis_by_reduction_of_methyl_compounds_with_H2		 #;Sowers et al., 1984; Von Klein et al., 2002; Singh et al. 2005; Kern et al., 2016, , Maestrojuán et al., 1992; Shimizu et al., 2011; Simankova et al., 2001; Lyimo et al., 2000; Elberson et al., 1997; Wagner et al., 2013; Ganzert et al., 2014; Shimizu et al., 2015; Zinder et al., 1985 	 #;acetoclastic methanogens mesophilic halotollerant from marine sediments; anaerobic digester; deep subsurface Miocene formation; psychrotolerant methanogenic from anoxic lake sediments;  dimethylsulfide-utilizing methanogen from mangrove sediment; marine canyon; desiccation and freeze-thaw resistant in siberian permafrost; floating biofilm of a subsurface sulphurous lake; deep subsurface diatomaceous shale formation; thermophilic acetotrophic methanogens(Sowers et al., 1984; Von Klein et al., 2002; Singh et al. 2005; Kern et al., 2016, , Maestrojuán et al., 1992; Shimizu et al., 2011; Simankova et al., 2001; Lyimo et al., 2000; Elberson et al., 1997; Wagner et al., 2013; Ganzert et al., 2014; Shimizu et al., 2015; Zinder et al., 1985

*Methanobacterium*	#methanogenesis_by_reduction_of_methyl_compounds_with_H2		 #;#Shlimon et al., 2004; Kern et al., 2015; SHCHERBAKOVA et al., 2011; Ma et al., 2005; Cuzin et al, 2001; KOTELNIKOVA et al.,1993 ; Mori et al., 2011; Patel et al., 1990; Zhu et al., 2011; Kitamura et al., 2011; Borrel et al., 2012; Schirmack et al., 2014; Joulian et al., 2000; Cadillo-Quiroz et al., 2014; Zellner et al, 1989; KOTELNIKOVA et al.,1998; Blotevogel et al., 1985; Zhilina et al., 1984; Touzel et al., 1992; König et al., 1984; KRIVUSHIN  et al., 2010; Winter et al., 1984 	 #;#Methanobacterium are hydrogenotrophs from marine sediment; anaerobic digester; artic permafrost; from fermented cassava peel; thermophilic anaerobic digester sludge; mesophilic and moderately acidiphilic; mesophilic from salty systems; from lake sediment; rice field; from sediment of a meromitcic lake; hydrogenotroph and secondary alchool methanogen; from northern peatlands; alkaliphilic, eurythermic and halotolerant methanogen from deep granitic groundwater; thermophilic and autotrophic methanogen; formate assimilating; from marshy soil; siberian permafrost (Shlimon et al., 2004; Kern et al., 2015; SHCHERBAKOVA et al., 2011; Ma et al., 2005; Cuzin et al, 2001; KOTELNIKOVA et al.,1993 ; Mori et al., 2011; Patel et al., 1990; Zhu et al., 2011; Kitamura et al., 2011; Borrel et al., 2012; Schirmack et al., 2014; Joulian et al., 2000; Cadillo-Quiroz et al., 2014; Zellner et al, 1989; KOTELNIKOVA et al.,1998; Blotevogel et al., 1985; Zhilina et al., 1984; Touzel et al., 1992; König et al., 1984; KRIVUSHIN  et al., 2010; Winter et al., 1984).

hydrogenotrophic_methanogenesis			 elements:C,H; main_element:C; electron_donor:H; electron_acceptor:C; aerobic:no; exclusively_prokaryotic:yes; light_dependent:no 										
# Use CO2 and H2 as sole energy source; 4H20 + CO2 --> CH4 + 2H2O			 #;# Thauer, R.K., Reaction and enzymes involved in methanigenesis from CO2 and H2. J.G. Ferry (Ed.), Methanogenesis, Chapman and Hall Co, New York (1993) 	#									
#			 #M. J. McInerney . T. Hoehler2 . R. P. Gunsalus . B. Schink. 2010. “Introduction to Microbial Hydrocarbon Production: Bioenergetics.” In Handbook of Hydrocarbon and Lipid Microbiology, Elsevier, 321–35. 	 #Lastly, two different groups of metha- nogens, the hydrogenotrophic methanogens and the acetotrophic methanogens, complete the process by converting the acetate, formate and hydrogen made by other microorganisms to methane and carbon dioxide (Deppenmeier, 2002; Hedderich and Whitman, 2006; Schaefer et al., 1999; Zinder, 1993).

methanogenesis_by_disproportionation_of_methyl_groups			 elements:C,H; main_element:C; electron_donor:none; electron_acceptor:none; aerobic:no; exclusively_prokaryotic:yes; light_dependent:no 										
#methylotrophic methanogenesis													
 #Methanosarcinales: unique methanogens with cytochromes (Thauer et al, 2008) 			#	#									
 #Methanosarcinaceae: universal methanogens, utilizing most of the possible substrates: acetoclastic (minimum of 1mM), methyl-reducing methanogen (Sowers et al., 1984) 			#	#

*Bathyarchaeia*	#aromatic_hydrocarbon_degradation	 #SILVA v.138, YES 	 # Farag, Ibrahim F. et al. 2020. “Metabolic Potentials of Archaeal Lineages Resolved from Metagenomes of Deep Costa Rica Sediments.” ISME Journal. http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/s41396-020-0615-5. 	 #; methyl-reducing and methylotrophic methanogenesis  + acetogenesis(Kallistova et al., 2017; Bizic-Ionescu et al., 2018); utilize CO2 for methanogenesis from TMA and acetogenesis; BCR complex in aromatic degradation 									
*Archaeoglobus*	#aromatic_hydrocarbon_degradation	 #SILVA v.138, YES 	 # Farag, Ibrahim F. et al. 2020. “Metabolic Potentials of Archaeal Lineages Resolved from Metagenomes of Deep Costa Rica Sediments.” ISME Journal. http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/s41396-020-0615-5. 	# BCR complex									
*Lokiarchaeia* 	#aromatic_hydrocarbon_degradation	 #SILVA v.138, YES 	 # Farag, Ibrahim F. et al. 2020. “Metabolic Potentials of Archaeal Lineages Resolved from Metagenomes of Deep Costa Rica Sediments.” ISME Journal. http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/s41396-020-0615-5. 	 # genes encoding for ?-oxidation enzymes (enoyl-CoA hydratase, acyl CoA dehydrogenase, and acetyl CoA acetyl transferase) and various fermentation pathways (acetate and formate) in Lokiarchaeota CR_06, which suggests that short chain fatty acid and different fermentation products could also be syntrophically exchanged (Table S4). Also, # BCR complex. Utilize aromatic hydrocarbons for acetogenesis and donate electrons for nitrite reducers in syntrophy; utilize butanoate and propionate and donates eelectrons for sulfite-reducers in syntrophy. The best conditions suggest that the degradation of benzoate (the central metabolic intermediate in aromatic hydrocarbon degradation pathways) potentially occurs under the following metabolic conditions (a, b, and c): (a) benzoate mineraliza- tion to CO2 and H2O coupled with nitrite reduction to ammonia (?rG? =?1206.3 [kJ/mol]); (b) benzoate miner- alization to CO2 and H2O coupled with sulfite reduction to hydrogen sulfide (?rG? =?373.6 [kJ/mol]); and (c) benzoate mineralization to CO2 and H2O coupled with nitrate reduc- tion to nitrite (?rG? =?119.9 [kJ/mol]).  The affiliations of the BCR complex related proteins, BCRA and BCRB in Lokiarchaeota CR_06 were confirmed by the following observations: (1) contigs encoding for the four subunits of BCR complex fall within the same cover- age and GC% range of the rest of the contigs in the same MAG (Fig. S2); (2) phylogenetic trees of the BzdO and Q protein sequences detected in the CR_06 were placed as siblings to BCR sequences belonging to Lokiarchaeota MAGs recovered from deep sediment from south China Sea (GenBank accession numbers TET61664 and TKJ21612). Lokiarchaeota (CR_06) MAG also suggests versatile catabolic capacities potentially targeting detrital proteins and short chain fatty acids (e.g., propano- ate, butyrate), which are abundant in benthic marine sedi- ments. . Both propanoate and oxobutanoate are converted to propanoyl CoA via formate acetyl transferase and acetyl synthase, respectively. Then, the resulting pro- panoyl CoA is converted to acetyl-CoA via the malonyl- CoA pathway. CR_06 as well as other Asgard phyla showed different autotrophic capacities enabling carbon fixation using both the Wood–Ljungdahl (WL) pathway and the reverse tricaboxylic acid (rTCA) cycle.

*Azoarcus*evansii*	#aromatic_compound_degradation		 # DOI:10.1099/00207713-45-2-327  and  Garrity, Brenner, Krieg and Staley (2005) Bergey's Manual of Systematic Bacteriology, vol. 2 	 # ATP-dependent Benzoyl-CoA reductase (BCR) complex class Bzd, which is composed of four subunits (BzdONPQ). This reaction can dearomatize the benzoyl-CoA to dienoyl-CoAs as the first step in aro- matic hydrocarbon degradation and then couple this reac- tion with a beta-oxidation pathway to ultimately produce acetyl-CoA, similar to the mechanism previously reported in the denitrifying bacteria Thauera aromatica

non_methane_hydrocarbon_production			elements:C; main_element:C; electron_donor:variable; electron_acceptor:C; aerobic:yes; exclusively_prokaryotic:yes; light_dependent:no										
 #lipids based cyclopentane and cyclohexane (naphtalene), and lipids-like as ether, C-halogen 			 #Wilkes, H., and J. Schwarzbauer. 2010. Handbook of Hydrocarbon and Lipid Microbiology Hydrocarbons and Lipids: An Introduction to Structure, Physico-Chemical Properties and Natural Occurrence. 	 #  (...) any heteroatom-containing compound, like alcohols, aldehydes, ketones, carboxylic acids, esters, sulfur compounds, amines, amides, and halides, of biogenic origin can be a lipid, as long as its hydrocarbon backbone is adequate to achieve a sufficient lipophilicity (see also chapter 5 Physical Properties).  ;   As the ether group is no hydrogen bond donor, ethers are poorly soluble in water and, therefore, can be considered as lipids or lipid-like compounds.  ;   Due to the moderate polarity of the C–halogen bond and their inability to form hydrogen bonds, organic halogen compounds are often quite lipophilic and thus behave like lipids.

#*Archaea*	#non_methane_hydrocarbon_production		#https://link.springer.com/referencework/10.1007/978-3-319-78108-2	 #produces lipids: isoprenoids (C-20 to C-40): Finally, all archaea synthesize significant amounts of isoprenoid lipids of C-20 to C40 chain length where considerable variation exists regarding the degree ofmolecule saturation, cyclization, and methylation (Koga and Morii, 2007). Archaeal isoprenoid biosyn- thesis proceeds by the mevalonic acid pathway or a modified version ofthis pathway involving isopentenyl-phosphate rather than diphosphomevalonic acid as an intermediate.

*Desulfovibrio*	#non_methane_hydrocarbon_production		 #Lu, Guan Yang et al. 2020. “Black Carbon as a Significant Component of Aromatic Carbon in Surface Soils and Its Importance Is Enhanced in Volcanic Ash Soil Profiles.” Organic Geochemistry 140: 103957. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.orggeochem.2019.103957. 	 #Hopanoids ((bacteriohopanepolyols, BHPs) in multiple bacterial groups are among the most widespread organic compounds in sediments and rocks. The capability of hopanoid production was thought to be restricted to aerobic bacteria but sev- eral recent studies have revealed production by specific anaerobic bacteria, including dissimilatory sul- fate reducers of the deltaproteobacterial genus Desulfovibrio.

# - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -				#									
#*Asgard*Candidatus_				#									
*Lokiarchaeota* 	#fermentation		 # Farag, Ibrahim F. et al. 2020. “Metabolic Potentials of Archaeal Lineages Resolved from Metagenomes of Deep Costa Rica Sediments.” ISME Journal. http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/s41396-020-0615-5. 	 # genes encoding for ?-oxidation enzymes (enoyl-CoA hydratase, acyl CoA dehydrogenase, and acetyl CoA acetyl transferase) and various fermentation pathways (acetate and formate) in Lokiarchaeota CR_06, which suggests that short chain fatty acid and different fermentation products could also be syntrophically exchanged (Table S4). Also, # BCR complex. Utilize aromatic hydrocarbons for acetogenesis and donate electrons for nitrite reducers in syntrophy; utilize butanoate and propionate and donates eelectrons for sulfite-reducers in syntrophy. The best conditions suggest that the degradation of benzoate (the central metabolic intermediate in aromatic hydrocarbon degradation pathways) potentially occurs under the following metabolic conditions (a, b, and c): (a) benzoate mineraliza- tion to CO2 and H2O coupled with nitrite reduction to ammonia (?rG? =?1206.3 [kJ/mol]); (b) benzoate miner- alization to CO2 and H2O coupled with sulfite reduction to hydrogen sulfide (?rG? =?373.6 [kJ/mol]); and (c) benzoate mineralization to CO2 and H2O coupled with nitrate reduc- tion to nitrite (?rG? =?119.9 [kJ/mol]).  The affiliations of the BCR complex related proteins, BCRA and BCRB in Lokiarchaeota CR_06 were confirmed by the following observations: (1) contigs encoding for the four subunits of BCR complex fall within the same cover- age and GC% range of the rest of the contigs in the same MAG (Fig. S2); (2) phylogenetic trees of the BzdO and Q protein sequences detected in the CR_06 were placed as siblings to BCR sequences belonging to Lokiarchaeota MAGs recovered from deep sediment from south China Sea (GenBank accession numbers TET61664 and TKJ21612). Lokiarchaeota (CR_06) MAG also suggests versatile catabolic capacities potentially targeting detrital proteins and short chain fatty acids (e.g., propano- ate, butyrate), which are abundant in benthic marine sedi- ments. . Both propanoate and oxobutanoate are converted to propanoyl CoA via formate acetyl transferase and acetyl synthase, respectively. Then, the resulting pro- panoyl CoA is converted to acetyl-CoA via the malonyl- CoA pathway. CR_06 as well as other Asgard phyla showed different autotrophic capacities enabling carbon fixation using both the Wood–Ljungdahl (WL) pathway and the reverse tricaboxylic acid (rTCA) cycle.

# using the command:													
#			 ./extract_regex_list_from_file.py -i 'List of human pathogens PATRIC.txt' -o human_pathogens_diarrhea.txt -n '^([^\s]+)\s+(\w+)\s+(\w+)[^\t]*\t(\d+)\t\[(.*Diarrhea.*)\]' --format '*$2$*$3$* # Pathosystems Resource Integration Centre (PATRIC). Genome ID: $1$, NCBI Taxon ID: $4$, Disease: $5$' --linewise -v -f --unique --uniqueness_format '$2$ $3$' --add_header_to_output --case_insensitive

#	 ./extract_regex_list_from_file.py -i 'List of human pathogens PATRIC.txt' -o human_pathogens_all.txt -n '^([^\s]+)\s+(\w+)\s+(\w+)[^\t]*\t(\d+)\t\[(.*)\]' --format '*$2$*$3$* # Pathosystems Resource Integration Centre (PATRIC). *Marine group I*			 #Heijs, Sander K., et al.   Microbial community structure in three deep-sea carbonate crusts.   Microbial Ecology 52.3 (2006): 451-462. 	 # by archaea from the Marine group I related archaea, Methanosarcinales, novel Thermoplasmales, and a group of novel Crenarchaea groups. The most frequent bacterial groups were Actinobacteria, Clostridia, alfa, delta, and Gamma Proteobacteria, Acidobacteria and OP-11 b, Chloroflexi and Verrucomicrobia  									
*Thermoplasmales*			 #Heijs, Sander K., et al.   Microbial community structure in three deep-sea carbonate crusts.   Microbial Ecology 52.3 (2006): 451-462. 	 # by archaea from the Marine group I related archaea, Methanosarcinales, novel Thermoplasmales, and a group of novel Crenarchaea groups. The most frequent bacterial groups were Actinobacteria, Clostridia, alfa, delta, and Gamma Proteobacteria, Acidobacteria and OP-11 b, Chloroflexi and Verrucomicrobia

#add_group:dark_sulfur_oxidation													
*Bathyarchaeia*			 #Ruff, S. E. et al. 2019. “In Situ Development of a Methanotrophic Microbiome in Deep-Sea Sediments.” ISME Journal 13(1): 197–213. http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/s41396-018-0263-1. 	 #Freshly erupted muds hosted deep-subsurface communities that were dominated by Bathyarchaeota, Atribacteria and Chloroflexi. Methanotrophy was initially limited to a thin surface layer of Methylococcales populations consuming methane aerobically. With increasing distance to the eruptive center, anaerobic methanotrophic archaea, sulfate- reducing Desulfobacterales and thiotrophic Beggiatoaceae developed, and their respective metabolic capabilities dominated the biogeochemical functions of the community. Microbial 									
*Bathyarchaeota*			 #Ruff, S. E. et al. 2019. “In Situ Development of a Methanotrophic Microbiome in Deep-Sea Sediments.” ISME Journal 13(1): 197–213. http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/s41396-018-0263-1. 	 #Freshly erupted muds hosted deep-subsurface communities that were dominated by Bathyarchaeota, Atribacteria and Chloroflexi. With increasing distance to the eruptive center, anaerobic methanotrophic archaea, sulfate- reducing Desulfobacterales and thiotrophic Beggiatoaceae developed, and their respective metabolic capabilities dominated the biogeochemical functions of the community.
